answers.answer: Yes, first even with perfect health visual acuity, like strength, speed, hearing, decreases with time. At age 80 you will not see as good as you did at 40, just like you can't run as fast. Second at age 80 you have some degee of catarct, everyone does this also will keep you from seeing as good as you want. Look at it this way, if you went to ****'s Sporting Goods and bought a $150 pair or funning shoes it won't help you run as fast as you once did.I would accept that the glasses are the best your eyes can have and go to a MD Eye Physician Ophthalmologist to determine why you don't see as good as you wish.JCH III MD

question: I recently had my eyes examined for a stronger prescription.  During the eye exam I can see clearly once the doctor gets to the correct lens but when I  get the eyeglasses with the actual prescription my vision is blurred.  The optometrist is telling me that I have the strongest prescription available.  I've been to a specialist for various testing and diabetes, high blood pressure and glaucoma have been ruled out as well as any other eye disease.   I had a  hemorraghe behind my left eye, but that too has been ruled out as a cause for the blurred vision with the new prescription.  I'm an 80 year old female and in good health.  The optometrist has re-examined my eyes to verify the prescription and is telling me it's correct.  It's a mystery.  Can you offer any suggestions?
title: stronger prescription isn't working
